article.description: Creighton proved it can also win with defense.
article.headline: Bluejays hit only 36 percent from field
article.linkText: Creighton proves it can win with defense, too
article.story:
PEORIA, Ill. (AP) -- Now Creighton knows it can shoot poorly and still win.

No. 16 Creighton had its worse shooting performance of the season but still managed to outlast Bradley 65-58 on Wednesday.

"It wasn't pretty, but it was probably something we needed,'' Kyle Korver said. "We're definitely lucky to get out of here with a win.''

The Bluejays (12-1, 3-0 Missouri Valley Conference) had not shot
less than 40 percent all season, and shot less than 50 percent just
three times.

But the Braves harassed Creighton all night, forcing them into
three second-half shot clock violations and holding them to 36
percent from the field and just 5-of-22 on 3-pointers.

"Things have been a little too easy in some of our games and we've jumped on teams early and when that didn't happen tonight, we lost some intensity,'' Creighton coach Dana Altman said. "With about 10 minutes left, we sensed we were in trouble and then we fought hard.''

A driving layup by Bradley's James Gillingham, who had stopped
the Bluejays forward Kyle Korver, brought the Braves within one
halfway through the second half.

The teams traded 3s and the Bluejays hit two free throws before
Bradley coach Jim Les was called for a technical foul.

Korver hit both free throws to push the lead to five and the
Braves never got closer than three. Korver made 25-of-37 shots in
the last three games and averaged nearly 26 points per game.

Gillingham, though, held him to seven points before a deep knee
bruise forced the Bradley guard to the sideline late in the game.

Korver finished 4-of-14, including 1-of-8 from beyond the arc,
scoring 13 points -- seven below his average.

"He was on me all night,'' Korver said. "He was always right
there.''

Korver hit his first three shots after Gillingham was injured.

Gilbert made his first three 3-point attempts and scored 13 of
the Braves first 15 points and 17 of their first 20. Gilbert made
6-of-7 shots while the rest of the Braves went 2-for-19.

"I'm proud of these guys,'' Les said. "We battled, toe-to-toe
with one of the best teams in the country. I'm happy with the
effort, but disappointed in the outcome.''

The Braves played without starting point guard Marcello
Robinson, who was benched for what Les called "lack of
commitment.'' Chris Mroz, a walk-on freshman started in Robinson's
spot and scored five points.

With the loss, Bradley dropped its 11th straight game against a ranked opponent, and fell to 0-6 all-time when playing a Top 25 team at Carver Arena.

Danny Granger scored 16 points, all in the second half, and Jabbar Battle grabbed 11 rebounds for the Braves.
